content: The commercial capital, Bujumbura. Burundi is classified as one of the poorest nations in the world in terms of GDP per capita, according to the World Bank
- Distinct Burundian kingdom emerges.
- The kingdoms of Urundi (Burundi) and neighbouring Ruanda (Rwanda) incorporated into German East Africa.
- Belgian army occupies the area.
- Belgium receives League of Nations mandate to administer Ruanda-Urundi.
- Influx of Tutsi refugees from Ruandan half of the territory following ethnic violence there.

- Independence drive led by cross-communal UPRONA party of Prince Louis Rwagasore, which wins 1961 legislative elections. Prince Louis becomes prime minister of Ruanda-Urundi  but is assassinated shortly afterwards. (NOTE Rwagasore was  Prime minister of only Burundi. Though the Ruanda-Urundi territory was under the same colonial administration with a resident general,  each country had its own local administration topped by the King as Head of state. Ruanda had its own King, and Burundi had its own).
- Burundi and Rwanda become independent as separate nations.
- King Mwambutsa refuses to appoint a Hutu prime minister after Hutus win a majority in parliamentary elections; attempted coup put down by army chief Michel Micombero.
- Michel Micombero abolishes the monarchy and declares himself president.
- About 120,000 Hutus are massacred by government forces and their supporters in the wake of a Hutu-led uprising in the south. Thousands of Hutus flee to Rwanda.
- President Micombero is deposed in a military coup by Jean-Baptiste Bagaza.
- A new constitution makes Burundi a one-party state under Uprona.
- President Bagaza is deposed in a coup led by Pierre Buyoya.

- Some Burundi Hutu refugees make an incursion from Rwanda into northern Burundi and massacre Tutsi people. Thousands odf Hutus are killed in subsequent Tutsi-dominated military reprisals in the area.
- New constitution providing for a multiparty system is adopted in a referendum.
- Melchior Ndadaye's Frodebu wins multi-party polls, ending military rule and leading to the installation of a pro-Hutu government.
Melchior Ndadaye was assassinated in 1993

October - Tutsi soldiers assassinate President Ndadaye. In revenge, some Frodebu members massacre Tutsis, and the army begins reprisals. Burundi is plunged into an ethnic conflict which claims some 300,000 lives.
January- Parliament appoints a Hutu, Cyprien Ntaryamira, as president.
Wreckage from the plane crash in which killed Burundi's former President Ntaryamira and his Rwandan opposite number
April - Plane carrying President Ntaryamira and his Rwandan counterpart is shot down over the Rwandan capital Kigali, killing both and triggering genocide in Rwanda in which 800,000 are killed.
October - Parliament speaker Sylvestre Ntibantunganya appointed president.
- Massacre of Hutu refugees leads to renewed ethnic violence in the capital, Bujumbura.
Pierre Buyoya (R) seized power twice
- Ex-president Buyoya seizes power.
October - Talks brokered by South African President Nelson Mandela lead to installation of transitional government, but main Hutu rebel groups refuse to sign and fighting intensifies.
April - Domitien Ndayizeye - a Hutu - succeeds Pierre Buyoya as president, under terms of three-year, power-sharing transitional government inaugurated in 2001.
July - Major rebel assault on Bujumbura. Some 300 rebels and 15 government soldiers are killed. Thousands flee their homes.

November - President Ndayizeye and Hutu rebel group Forces for Defence of Democracy (FDD) leader Pierre Nkurunziza sign agreement to end the civil war at summit of African leaders in Tanzania. Smaller Hutu rebel group, Forces for National Liberation (FNL), remains active.
- UN force takes over peacekeeping duties from African Union troops.
January - President signs law to set up new national army, incorporating government forces and all but one Hutu rebel group, the FNL.
August - Pierre Nkurunziza, from the Hutu FDD group, is elected as president by the two houses of parliament. The FDD won parliamentary elections in June.
April - A curfew, imposed during the violence of 1972, is lifted.
September - The last major rebel group, the Forces for National Liberation (FNL), and the government sign a ceasefire at talks in Tanzania. Sporadic clashes recur over the next two years.
February - UN shuts down its peacekeeping mission and refocuses its operations on helping with reconstruction.
April - DR Congo, Rwanda and Burundi relaunch the regional economic bloc - Great Lakes Countries Economic Community - known under its French acronym CEPGL.
December - Burundian soldiers join African Union peacekeepers in Somalia.
March - The Paris Club of creditor nations cancels all of the $134.3m debt Burundi owed to its members.
April - FNL lays down arms and officially becomes a political party in a ceremony supervised by the African Union.
June - President Nkurunziza re-elected in uncontested poll after main opposition parties boycott the vote.
June - President Nkurunziza approves new media law which critics condemn as an attack on press freedom.
August - The leader of the former rebel FML, Agathon Rwasa, resurfaces after three years in hiding and says he will stand in the 2015 presidential election.
Burundian troops have been part of an African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia since 2007 and have suffered some casualties
March - Parliament blocks a government attempt to introduce changes to the constitution seen as threatening the balance of power between the country's main ethnic groups.
President Pierre Nkurunziza's decision to stand for a third term prompted months of protests

May - Constitutional Court rules in favour of President Nkurunziza's decision to stand for a third term, amid reports of judges being intimidated. Protestors take to the streets and tens of thousands flee the violence. An army officer's coup attempt fails.
July - President Nkurunziza wins a third term in the presidential election with 70% of the vote. Opposition leader Agathon Rwasa describes the polls as a "joke".

January - President Nkurunziza threatens to counter the deployment of external peacekeepers after the African Union announces plans to send in 5,000 troops to protect civilians from escalating violence between government and rebel forces.
Critics accused Pierre Nkurunziza of authoritarian tendencies
March - With the political situation showing little sign of improvement, the EU announces that it is suspending direct financial aid to the Burundian government.
October - Burundi becomes the first ever country to leave the International Criminal Court (ICC).
November - ICC judges approve the opening of a full investigation into alleged crimes against humanity in Burundi, where at least 1,200 people have died in unrest since 2015.
May - Official results say a referendum backed constitutional reforms that could allow President Nkurunziza to stay in office for another sixteen years.

December - Burundi issues international arrest warrant for former president Pierre Buyoya over the killing of President Melchior Ndadaye in 1993. Mr Buyoya's supporters say the move is politically motivated.
April - Capital moved to Gitega, although Bujumbura remains the commercial capital.
June - Former Hutu rebel leader Evariste Ndayishimiye takes office as president, a week after President Pierre Nkurunziza died suddenly in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic.
